entry.title: New Nurse Advice Line
entry.summary: The Student Health Services for The Claremont Colleges, has a new "Nurse Advice" phone service.  Students can call the office during office hours and speak with a registered nurse for advice or to determine if the student needs to be...
entry.content: The Student Health Services for The Claremont Colleges, has a new "Nurse Advice" phone service.  Students can call the office during office hours and speak with a registered nurse for advice or to determine if the student needs to be seen by a medical provider that day or for a future appointment. If the nurse is unable to answer the phone, students may leave a message and the advice nurse will return the call between 8 am to 4 pm. Students can get self-care help and instructions for conditions including  upset stomach, cold symptoms, fever, sore throat, and rash.  The nurses can also answer questions about birth control or sexually transmitted infection concerns. Patients may be directed to see a medical provider at the Student Health Services or be advised to go to the local urgent care center or emergency room department if needed. On call services are still available after office hours through campus safety at (909) 607-2000.

entry.title: Meningitis information and prevention
entry.summary: Student Health Services has been following the recent outbreaks of meningitis at Princeton University and the University of California-Santa Barbara.  To date there have been no reported cases of meningitis at The Claremont Colleges.  Please be advised that we are...
entry.content:
Student Health Services has been following the recent outbreaks of meningitis at Princeton University and the University of California-Santa Barbara.  To date there have been no reported cases of meningitis at The Claremont Colleges.  Please be advised that we are monitoring this situation closely and we are following the Centers for Disease Control and the Los Angeles Public Health Department's recommendations. Signs and symptoms
  • Sudden onset of fever
  • Headache
  • Stiff neck

Often other symptoms may develop

  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Increased sensitivity to light (photophobia)
  • Altered mental status (confusion)

The symptoms of bacterial meningitis can appear quickly or over several days. Typically they develop within 3-7 days after exposure.  Later symptoms of bacterial meningitis can be very severe (e.g., seizures, coma). For this reason, anyone who thinks they may have meningitis should see a doctor as soon as possible.

Treatment

Bacterial meningitis can be treated effectively with antibiotics.  It is important that treatment be started as soon as possible.  Appropriate antibiotic treatment of the most common types of bacterial meningitis should reduce the risk of dying from meningitis to below 15%, although the risk remains higher among young infants and the elderly.

Prevention

The most effective way to prevent meningitis is to get the meningococcal vaccine which is available at Student Health Services.  Maintaining healthy habits, like not smoking and avoiding cigarette smoke, getting plenty of rest, and not coming into close contact with people who are sick, can also help. This is especially important for young infants, the elderly, or for those with a weakened immune system, since they are at increased risk for severe disease.  You can help prevent the spread of disease by increasing hygienic practices, and not sharing drinking glasses, eating utensils, smoking materials, and other items.

Please contact Student Health Services at (909) 621-8222 for any questions or concerns or contact your healthcare provider when school is not in session.  For further information you may also check the Centers for Disease Control.

Thanks,

Jennie Ho, MD | Director | Student Health Services

entry.title: Fall 2013–14
entry.summary: Student Health Services, (SHS), will be officially opened for the fall on September 2,  Labor Day.  We have a fully scheduled staff to handle, appointments and prescription refills, lab and x-ray, as well as walk-in patient care.  The health center...
entry.content: Student Health Services, (SHS), will be officially opened for the fall on September 2,  Labor Day.  We have a fully scheduled staff to handle, appointments and prescription refills, lab and x-ray, as well as walk-in patient care.  The health center will be open the week of August 26 thru 30 with limited staffing.  Students may make future appointments during this time or become a walk-in patient.  SHS will waive the normal fee of $15.00 for any walk-in patient in August, however, as of September 2, 2013, Student Health Services will initiate  the $15.00 fee for all walk-in patients.

entry.title: Walk-in appointments
entry.summary: Student Health Services (SHS) provides walk-in appointments for students who have urgent medical needs. The charge for the service is $15.00.  A walk-in patient will be seen by a Registered Nurse who will assess the medical needs of the patient....
entry.content:
Student Health Services (SHS) provides walk-in appointments for students who have urgent medical needs. The charge for the service is $15.00.  A walk-in patient will be seen by a Registered Nurse who will assess the medical needs of the patient. If it is determined that the patient has an urgent medical need, the Registered Nurse will refer the patient to one of the Student Health Services providers.  If it is determined by the Registered Nurse that the medical condition is not urgent, treatment recommendation(s) will be provided. A walk-in patient may experience an extended wait time depending on the number of walk-in patients in the reception area.

If a student needs medical attention, he or she may schedule an appointment. Same day appointments are typically available in the afternoon.

The SHS nurse is always available for a consultation regarding your immediate health concerns.  A conversation with one of our nurses may assist you in your decision to walk-in or make an appointment. SHS works hard to provide the best care possible for all students at the Claremont Colleges, whether by appointment, phone consultation, or as a walk-in patient.

entry.title: Flu 2013–14
entry.summary: Flu shots will be available by appointment in the fall.  You can call after September 15th for more complete information and appointment availability....
entry.content:
Flu shots will be available by appointment in the fall.  You can call after September 15th for more complete information and appointment availability.

Student Health Services and Health Education Outreach have scheduled our annual flu clinics.  Please note the times and dates below, however, information will be posted regarding our clinic schedule in September. There will be a charge, payable at the clinic, or students may use their college sponsored insurance program. Students may pay by cash, check, Claremont Cash or personal credit card (MasterCard or Visa). A receipt will be provided that can be submitted to personal insurance carriers for reimbursement. The following dates and locations are listed below:

October 7 Pomona Campus, Frank Blue Room
October 8 CMC Campus, Collins Green Dining Room
October 9 Scripps Campus, Hampton Room
October 10 Pitzer, McConnell Living Room
October 11 HMC Campus, Hoch-Shanahan Aviation Room
October 15 KGI Campus
October 16 CGU Campus, Location will be posted
October 23 Tranquada MPR -- Open to All
October 27 Tranquada MPR -- Open to All

entry.title: Student Health Insurance Plan for 2013-2014
entry.summary: Information regarding the student insurance program may be accessed through the Student Health Services website.  Under the heading Download, the 2013–2014 Student Health Insurance Summary Plan [pdf] is available for review.  A complete brochure and additional contact information is available....
entry.content: Information regarding the student insurance program may be accessed through the Student Health Services website.  Under the heading Download, the 2013–2014 Student Health Insurance Summary Plan [pdf] is available for review.  A complete brochure and additional contact information is available. Student Health Services does not do any direct billing for this or any other insurance carrier. Student Health Services will provide all patients with a complete "walk-out" sheet that can be submitted to any insurance claims department.

entry.title: Summer break
entry.summary: Student Health Services (SHS, MCAPS & HEO) will be closed as of May 17th until August 26, 2013. All incoming freshman for Fall 2013, must submit their Entrance Forms by the 1st of August 2013. We do suggest that you...
entry.content:
Student Health Services (SHS, MCAPS & HEO) will be closed as of May 17th until August 26, 2013. All incoming freshman for Fall 2013, must submit their Entrance Forms by the 1st of August 2013. We do suggest that you view our joint website for complete information regarding our services and some of the most frequently asked questions. Although all offices are closed, if you have any questions regarding this form, request for medical files, or general information you may leave a voice mail which will be checked periodically.

Services during summer break: A list of emergency care or medical providers within our community is available on the SHS website's Resources page. We recommend that you discuss your insurance coverage directly with the medical facility or refer to your carrier for information regarding coverage.

entry.title: Annual patient satisfaction survey
entry.summary: Student Health Services (SHS) has completed its annual patient satisfaction survey.  SHS provides a wide range of medical services to support students of The Claremont Colleges.  SHS sets a high standard for medical care and customer service.  We ask the...
entry.content:
Student Health Services (SHS) has completed its annual patient satisfaction survey.  SHS provides a wide range of medical services to support students of The Claremont Colleges.  SHS sets a high standard for medical care and customer service.  We ask the students for their feedback to evaluate our performance.  A section is provided to give students an opportunity to comment on services or to make a suggestion or to ask a question.  In response to the comments and to acknowledge the students' questions, here are the answers to the two questions that may affect a number of students.
  1. Why is it so difficult to get an appointment?
    Patients may find it difficult to schedule an appointment for several reasons:
    1. The number of appointments available is a result of utilization by students and the number of medical providers. Appointments are filled on a first available system. Some specialty appointments (i.e. sports physicals, women's wellness and study abroad physicals) are scheduled at specific times to prevent extended wait times.
    2. Matching student schedules with available appointments in Student Health Services. If the patient has to miss a class in order to be seen, SHS will issue a provider note at the time of the appointment. We are also open on Wednesday evening for appointments and the patient may also speak with a Registered Nurse at any time between 8:00 - 5:00. The scheduling of appointments can be a little more difficult when the campus is experiencing an increase in specific health issues (i.e. Seasonal flu or other communicable diseases). During these times SHS does its best to provide additional care or a student may go to urgent care. Urgent care information is posted on the SHS website with addresses and phone numbers. Students are cautioned to make sure that the Student Health Insurance is applicable at these facilities.
    3. If a student's travel or possible employment requires them to get a physical, the best advice would be to contact SHS and schedule an appointment as soon as possible. This gives the student a better opportunity to schedule an appointment according to their own class schedule. If a student finds they do not feel well and there are no available same day appointments, they may come in as a walk-in patient and be worked into the schedule. Please understand that the SHS staff does its best to see all patients , but a walk-in student may have to wait a considerable time before being seen by a provider. Walk-in patients will be seen by a Registered Nurse first. Once again, a student can go to urgent care or call the staff nurse for advice.
  2. Why is it so much more expensive to get a single common STD test then to get a bundle of all of them?
    Due to the outside lab costs a single test may be more costly than a bundle (multiple tests). Our outside lab has provided us with some costing benefits and designed a group of panels, based on the needs of college aged patients. SHS is consistently reviewing our lab services and costs to make sure we are providing the best possible service at the most affordable price. Students are able to get free HIV testing and OTC pregnancy tests from Health Education Outreach (HEO).

entry.title: Entrance physicals
entry.summary: Freshman students may submit completed Entrance Physicals via fax, e-mail and US mail. The e-mail address can be found on Page 1 of the Entrance Physical Form.  Please note that the forms must be submitted via e-mail as a PDF....
entry.content: Freshman students may submit completed Entrance Physicals via fax, e-mail and US mail. The e-mail address can be found on Page 1 of the Entrance Physical Form.  Please note that the forms must be submitted via e-mail as a PDF. The Entrance Physicals MUST include the signature of a physician, immunization records and signed by the entering student. The forms are reviewed for completion and may be returned if not completed.

entry.title: Request for medical records
entry.summary: Request for medical records from Student Health may be made during the summer break via a letter or submitting a signed Medical Release form.  [More complete information can be found on the SHS website forms page (the SHS website under...
entry.content:
Request for medical records from Student Health may be made during the summer break via a letter or submitting a signed Medical Release form.  [More complete information can be found on the SHS website forms page (the SHS website under "Go To" heading, "Forms").]

Request for medical records from Monsour Counseling may be made during the summer break via a letter or submitting a signed Release form.    [More complete information can be found on the SHS website forms page (the SHS website under "Go To" heading, "Forms").]

entry.title: What's new at student health
entry.summary: Student Health has entered the world of technology, with electronic medical records (EMR).  This has allowed us to streamline many of the services that Student Health offers its patients. We now have electronic check-in for those students who have made...
entry.content:
Student Health has entered the world of technology, with electronic medical records (EMR).  This has allowed us to streamline many of the services that Student Health offers its patients. We now have electronic check-in for those students who have made an appointment.  Our x-ray department has installed a digital x-ray system, that will also enable us to provide a copy of a student's x-ray on a CD. Our dispensary and lab  are also part of the new system, which we feel provides our students with a level of care that is our commitment to the Claremont Colleges.

We are now accepting credit cards for payment for additional services provided our patients.  We accept Mastercard and Visa as well as Claremont Cash. If bills are not paid at time of service patients have 30 days before the balance is submitted to their student account for payment.  We encourage all graduating seniors to pay their bill in full, prior to SHS closing for the summer.

entry.title: Summer break is coming to an end
entry.summary: Summer break is coming to an end.  Student Health Services will be open for students as follows:Monsour Counseling will be open for appointment August 30th from 8:00 am to 5:00 pm.  You may call to make an appointment beginning Monday...
entry.content:
Summer break is coming to an end.  Student Health Services will be open for students as follows:

Monsour Counseling will be open for appointment August 30th from 8:00 am to 5:00 pm.  You may call to make an appointment beginning Monday August 22nd.

Student Health Services will be open the week of August 22nd for walk-in appointments 8:15 am to 5:00 pm.  The week of August 30th SHS will begin seeing patients who have scheduled an appointment.

HEO will be open for students beginning August 30th.  

Please refer to each website for complete information.

entry.title: Summer closing, May 16 to August 26: Student Health, Monsour Counseling, Health Education Outreach
entry.summary: If you need health care during the summer a list of emergency care or medical providers within our community is available on the SHS website ("Students Health Center Resources"). Or you can access this information from our SHS website under...
entry.content:
If you need health care during the summer a list of emergency care or medical providers within our community is available on the SHS website ("Students Health Center Resources"). Or you can access this information from our SHS website under "Go To" heading and then Resources.
Request for medical records from Student Health may be made during the summer break via a letter or submitting a signed Medical Release form.  More complete information can be found on the SHS website ("Students Health Center Forms"). Or you can access this information from our SHS website under "Go To" heading and then Forms.

Request for medical records from Monsour Counseling may be made during the summer break via a letter or submitting a signed Release form.  More complete information can be found on the SHS website. Or you can access this information from our SHS website under "Go To" heading and then Forms.

Information regarding the College Student Health Insurance can be found on all Student Services' Websites.  On any of our sites you will find a link to the 2011-2012 Student Accident and Sickness Insurance Plan, under the "Download" heading. For additional information, you may access the carrier's website.

Please view our Health Center News in the fall when we will have information regarding our Flu clinic dates and locations planned for early Fall.

entry.title: Recent Events in Japan
entry.summary: We are shocked and saddened by the continuing devastating news in Japan following a magnitude 9.0 offshore quake and resulting tsunami. The disaster impacts the entire campus community - staff, students, faculty and alumni. Some of us may have family...
entry.content:
We are shocked and saddened by the continuing devastating news in Japan following a magnitude 9.0 offshore quake and resulting tsunami. The disaster impacts the entire campus community - staff, students, faculty and alumni. Some of us may have family members, relatives, friends, and colleagues affected directly or indirectly by the disaster.   As we continue to receive reports of the devastating effects of the earthquake and tsunami in Japan, it's important to know that caring support and resources are immediately available to our Claremont College's community.  We hope that you will contact us if you are struggling yourself or worried about another in our community.

Counseling Services

Counselors at MCAPS are available for all enrolled 7C students on campus.  To make an appointment or speak to a counselor, please call (909) 621-8202 (or X-18202).   Appointments can be made Monday through Friday, 8:30  a.m. to 5 p.m., at MCAPS located in the Robert Tranquada Student Center.  On-call services for emergencies are also available after hours by calling campus safety (909) 621-8170 (or X-18170) and asking them to page the on call psychologist.

Common Reactions to Traumatic News and Events

It is natural to be upset about the disaster in Japan and to be worried about threats to you and your loved ones. Feeling anxious about the unknown is normal and public health alerts can have powerful effects on people of all ages. While coping with these feelings during times of uncertainty can be challenging, please remember you are not alone. 

Common stress reactions: Although people react in their own way, here are some reactions you might experience physical, emotional, mental, and behavioral symptoms:

Physical
Headaches, tiredness
Fast pulse, high blood pressure
Changes in appetite
Unexplained aches or pains
Trouble sleeping or sleeping too much
Stomach aches

Emotional
panic, anxiety
distrust, fear
anger, irritability, blame
feeling overwhelmed
sadness, depression
increased stress
feeling vulnerable or unsafe

Mental
Difficulty concentrating
Problems with work or school
Memory problems
Troubling thoughts that won't go away
Concern about health issues
           
Behavioral
Avoiding others
Increased substance use
Excessive cleaning or washing
Being overly cautious, jumpiness

Shifts in priorities, worldview and appreciation of others can also occur. It is also normal to have no reaction at all.

Coping with these Reactions


People can take steps to help themselves, family members and each other cope with these stress reactions.  Here is a list of self-help suggestions:

·         Limit your exposure to graphic news stories:  although it is difficult to resist the news, this can lead to stronger stress reactions. Consider turning off  tv, and limiting exposure to internet news and videos, especially if you feel anxious after watching or if your sleep is affected. 

·         Get accurate, timely information from reliable sources.  Educate yourself about the specific health hazards rather than jumping to worst case scenarios.

·         Maintain your normal daily routine as much as possible.  Don't make big life changes

·         Experience your feelings--you have the right to have feelings even if you are not directly affected

·         Remind yourself that you are normal and having normal reactions

·         Talk with someone about your feelings, even if it is difficult

·         Stay in touch with family and friends

·         Academically, you may have trouble concentrating in class, taking notes, writing, focusing on reading and performing on tests. Talk to your professors and GSIs about extensions if necessary.

·         Exercise, eat well and rest. Watch alcohol intake 

·         Be good to yourself--do things that make you feel better. Take breaks, schedule pleasant activities, engaging in positive distracting activities (sports, hobbies, reading).  

·          Find Strength and comfort in your spiritual and personal beliefs.

 Remember that each person can experience trauma differently and that you and others may have different needs at different times; try to be flexible

When and How to Seek Help

"When in doubt... reach out"           

·         Intense feelings of anxiety or hopelessness

·         Trouble performing daily activities

·         Disorientation

·         Inability to care for self

·         Suicidal or destructive thoughts

  • Problematic use of alcohol/drugs

Additional Coping Resources from the American Psychological Association

·         Managing traumatic stress: Tips for recovering from disasters and other traumatic events

·         Managing traumatic stress: Dealing with the hurricanes from afar

Red Cross

The best way to contact or locate U.S. citizens living or traveling in Japan is to contact the U.S. Department of State, Office of Overseas Citizens Services, at 1-888-407-4747 or (202) 647-5225. The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) has offered to assist Japan with restoring family links.

·         In addition, with ongoing evacuations in the United States, the Red Cross Safe and Well website is a secure and easy-to-use online tool that helps families connect during emergencies like tsunamis. There are several easy ways to register yourself or search for a loved one on the Safe and Well website: from a computer, visit www.redcross.org, from a smartphone visit www.redcross.org/safeandwell or from any phone, call 1-800-RED CROSS (1-800-733-2767) for help registering.

The additional resources listed below are available in English and in Japanese. 

·         Psychological First Aid (Japanese Version) can be accessed on the home page of the NCTSN website (www.nctsn.org).
The Psychological First Aid Field Operations Guide (Second Edition), developed by NCTSN and the National Center for PTSD, is an evidence-informed intervention to help children, adolescents, adults, and families in the immediate aftermath of disaster. Psychological First Aid is designed to reduce initial distress caused by disasters, and to foster short- and long-term adaptive functioning and coping.

  • The Hyogo Institute for Traumatic Stress, established after the Great Hanshin-Awaji Earthquake in 1995, provides traumatic stress resources in Japanese (www.j-hits.org).
